awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Artificial Intelligence & Deep Learning (AIDL) Training and Research Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers in health, biomedical science, and various engineering fields often do not receive sufficient training in using the most powerful approach to machine learning known to date, an approach called "deep learning", for analying their data.  Deep learning is based on simulated artificial neural networks, and for large real-world problems requires access to specialized computer hardward and software.  Such hardware and software platforms, however, are rarely part of the information technology resources available for researchers outside of the field of computer science.  This project will overcome this barrier by procurement and development of a deep learning platform at Florida Atlantic University for such research.  The project provides a training hub for industry and university to work closely on advanced artificial intelligence applications, and in turn might benefit economic growth.

This infrastructure project supports creation of a deep learning platform for health, biomedicine, ocean research, and related domains at Florida Atlantic University.  The platform will be shared across campus to service multiple domains. The project brings about a centralized cross campus interdisciplinary platform and augmented deep learning and related artificial intelligence tools for interdisciplinary research.  The former, jointly managed by the College of Engineering and Computer Science, and the FAU office of Information Technology, enables building upon the experience and frameworks of others that eventually results in shared infrastructure savings. The latter is likely to contribute in building/augmenting AI and DL tool kits for interdisciplinary research, including augmentation of existing common machine learning and deep learning algorithms for domain experts to carry out analysis on their data without requiring intensive programming skills. Augmented AI and DL tools should be particularly useful to ocean engineers and health sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Project Goal: This MRI infrastructure project supports creation of a deep learning platform for health, biomedicine, ocean research, and related domains at Florida Atlantic University (FAU). The platform will be shared across campus to service multiple domains. The project brings about a centralized cross campus interdisciplinary platform and augmented deep learning and related artificial intelligence tools for interdisciplinary research.

 

MRI Instrument: The established NSF AIDL GPU cluster features 64 Nvidia Tesla V-100 GPU cards and 6 Nvidia Tesla A-100 GPU cards. The server, placed at the FAU Jupiter campus high performance computing center, is jointly managed by the FAU College of Engineering and Computer Science, and the FAU office of information technology (OIT). The server was commenced on November 26 2019, and has been actively providing services to all FAU community since then on. From January 1 2020 till December 16 2021, the AIDL server has provided 743,963 GPU computing hour services to the FAU community. During this period, the server received 325,478 job tasks. Among submitted tasks, 153,385 tasks have been completed, representing a 47.12% job task completion ratio (153,385/325,478). This task completion ratio is higher than the task completion ratio we reported in previous year (2020 report), which was 38.92%, indicating that the training and instruction efforts we have provided help AIDL server users to get familiar with the usage of the server to support their computing tasks.

 

Research Outcomes: As the original planed research goal, the NSF AIDL server has been served as a major research infrastructure to support MRI team?s research activities. During the founding period, our research has resulted in 43 peer reviewed publications (we only count publications from the MRI project PIs, and all 43 publications have acknowledged the NSF MRI project support). Several papers are still under review and will be added to the project outcomes after being accepted for publication.

 

The 43 peer reviewed publications include 23 journal papers and 20 conference proceeding papers. Many of these publications are published at top tier venues, such as IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics, IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, IEEE Transactions on Big Data, ACM Transactions on Knowledge discovery from Data, ACM Computing Survey, etc.

 

The publications are centered around using deep learning algorithms or tools to solve domain application challenges. The domains related to our study include clinical trial analysis, hospital readmission, online advertising and recommendation, oceanographic and marine animal behavior study, image processing, social network analysis, graph and network learning, stock market analysis etc.

 

 Teaching and training Activities: The deployment of the NSF MRI instrument is paired with the PI?s teaching and curriculum development activities. During the funding period, the PI has been using NSF MRI instrument in seven graduate courses, with 399 graduate students being trained. The classes cover a variety of computing related subjects, such as deep learning, neural networks, artificial intelligence, big data and social network analytics, and data science capstone etc.

 

Many of these graduate students are from the areas outside the Engineering field, such as College of Science, College of Nursing, College of Business etc. For each of the graduate course, a hands-on training session has been designed to allow student to set up FAU HPC account, using web portal (https://ondemand.hpc.fau.edu) to reschedule resources, and launch computing tasks. In addition, specific term projects are also designed for students to practice on developing solutions to solve class subject related tasks, such as designing intelligent learning agents (for artificial intelligence class) or deep learning approaches to recognize images from different categories (for deep learning class).

 

Conclusion: The NSF MRI project has achieved the original planned research and training goal. The shared cross campus computing platform is actively serving the whole FAU community to support interdisciplinary research, curriculum development and teaching enhancement, and career preparation and workforce training.

 


Last Modified: 02/03/2022
Modified by: Xingquan Zhu
